Our full [rules](https://www.reddit.com/r/Ask_Politics/wiki/rules) can be found here, but are summarized below.  * Address the question (and its replies) in a professional manner * Avoid personal attacks and partisan "point scoring" * Avoid the use of partisan slang and [fallacies](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_fallacies) * Provide sources if possible at the time of commenting.  **If asked, you must provide sources.** * Help avoid the echo chamber - downvote bad/poorly sourced responses, not responses you disagree with.  **Do not downvote just because you disagree with the response**. * Report any comments that do not meet our standards and rules.  Further, all submissions are subject to manual review.  If you have any questions, please contact the mods at any time.   *I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Comment: Do you mean the physical seats in parliament?  The procedure may differ per country, but for the Netherlands it is the chairperson of the lower chamber who decides, with input from the political parties themselves. The lower chamber is more than half-round, with six 'slices' of seats, each slice having two seats at the front. Since these are most visible on TV it is tradition that the six largest political parties get at least those seats. All parties are mostly seated left to right according to ideology. Smaller parties get to have access to one of the aisles, so they can easily come to the interruption microphones at the front.  Apparently Iceland assigns seats per lot, thereby mixing candidates of all parties around, which is rather interesting.
Author: PoliticalAnimalIsOwl
